In order to better analyze this argument, I have created an Excel table summarizing the beliefs of a sample of scientists regarding the existence of a god. 
Scientist Name | Belief in God 
----------------|---------------
Dr. X | Believes in God 
Dr. Y | Does not believe in God 
Dr. Z | Undecided 
Dr. A | Believes in God 
Dr. B | Does not believe in God 
Using this table, we can see that the argument "All scientists reject the notion of a god, so clearly god does not exist" is flawed. 
What fallacy is present in this argument?

The argument "All scientists reject the notion of a god, so clearly god does not exist" is an example of the "hasty generalization" fallacy. This fallacy occurs when a conclusion is drawn from a sample that is too small or not representative of the whole population. In this case, assuming that the belief of all scientists can be determined from a small sample and then using that assumption to make a broader claim about the existence of God is a hasty generalization. Additionally, this argument might also involve an "appeal to authority" fallacy, where the opinion of scientists is used as the sole basis for the truth of a non-scientific claim, such as the existence of God, which is inherently a philosophical or theological question rather than a scientific one.
